title: Lloyds chairman warns on EU membership
text:
Lloyds chairman warns Britain’s EU membership is not sustainable Emma Dunkley Comments Lord Norman Blackwell 
The chairman of Lloyds Banking Group , in a rare public intervention on the Brexit debate by a senior banker, has warned that Britain’s membership of the EU is not sustainable without “significant change”. 
Lord Norman Blackwell, a Conservative peer, said Britain “is likely to remain an attractive global location” whatever the outcome of the referendum on EU membership, which will be held by the end of 2017. More Tribunal throws out MPs’ spies complaint 
His comments at a parliamentary debate on Tuesday, made in a personal capacity rather than on behalf of the bank, will be viewed as a boost to the “out” campaign as arguments on both sides of the referendum debate gather momentum. 
Stuart Rose, the former chairman of Marks and Spencer, is spearheading the Britain Stronger in Europe campaign launched earlier this week, backed by business heavyweights including Virgin boss Richard Branson. 
But Lord Blackwell, a former adviser to Margaret Thatcher and John Major, said: “I don’t agree that remaining in the European Union without a significant change in the current arrangements is ultimately sustainable from a political and constitutional perspective.” 
He said the continued drive towards political and economic union among eurozone members, while necessary for the euro to survive, means the current position of the UK “may become increasingly unsustainable”. 
“We are not and never will be part of the eurozone, so the reality is that we cannot be at the heart of a European Union that becomes increasingly focused on the governance and political decision-making of an integrated eurozone core,” he added. 
Lord Blackwell conceded that it would be “simplest” to stay in the single market if the City of London’s global competitiveness can be protected from “unwelcome regulation”. 
“However, whatever the nature of our relationship that emerges, it is clearly in the interests of both UK and European business to maintain a trade arrangement,” he said. 
“There are voices on both sides of that argument, but in the end our global competitiveness in the fast-growing markets outside the European Union must be a primary concern.” 
Lord Lawson of Blaby, the former Conservative chancellor, said in the hearing that “the time has come to rediscover out national self-confidence”. 
“The regulatory burden imposed by membership of the European Union in the case of the United Kingdom has been calculated to cost something like £25 billion a year,” he said. 
He urged Britain to “abandon a political project that we do not share,” and instead “embrace a global future”. Related Topics
